caption_original:
With all the hurricane activity in the Atlantic Basin, Canadians are wondering if climate change is to blame. 

Meteorologists from the Canadian Hurricane Centre at Environment and Climate Change Canada see a difference in storm projections. Climate change may have a variety of impacts on hurricanes, such as stronger winds and more rain. Be prepared!

caption_original:
This weekend, Canada and the world celebrated the 30th anniversary of the Montreal Protocol. The Montreal Protocol is a historic international agreement that has eliminated over 99% of substances that were thinning the earth’s ozone layer. 

Like the Paris Agreement, it shows the amazing things we can accomplish when countries work together on a common goal. It’s a reminder of what the world needs to continue to do to address the global threat of climate change.
caption_cleaned: This weekend, Canada and the world celebrated the th anniversary of the Montreal Protocol. The Montreal Protocol is a historic international agreement that has eliminated over % of substances that were thinning the earth’s ozone layer. Like the Paris Agreement, it shows the amazing things we can accomplish when countries work together on a common goal. It’s a reminder of what the world needs to continue to do to address the global threat of climate change.

caption_original:
Climate change presents risks to our health, homes, finances, water and food as well as to our ecosystems. What concerns you most about climate change? Take our survey and let us know! Your views will help inform Canada in a Changing Climate, a series of authoritative science and information products on how Canada’s climate is changing, the impacts of these changes and how we’re adapting to reduce risk.

And while you’re there, sign up to review these products as they’re being drafted! 
http://ow.ly/JBwY30f4AMX

And while you’re there, sign up to review these products as they’re being drafted!

caption_original:
As a Science Horizons interns, Mesha helped coordinate the Great St. Lawrence River Clean-up that saw volunteers remove an impressive 12 tonnes of waste from the river and shoreline. Mesha helped recruit and organize some 400 volunteers and provided them with safety training and technical support for the Great St. Lawrence Clean-up. St. Lawrence River Institute of Environmental Sciences 

The logo for this initiative — kaniionta — means little fish or minnow in Mohawk, and symbolizes that out of little things, big things come. 

Find out how you can make a difference working in the environmental field. Apply for a Science Horizons Youth Internship today! http://ow.ly/BqHu30flP5s

caption_original:
We are creating a souvenir album celebrating 100 years of bird conservation in Canada. Share with us your bird anecdotes or thoughts on birds today!

The album will be a tribute to birds and all those who love them, volunteer bird observers, or those who have even devoted their career to bird conservation. The album will contain testimonials and photos of 100 people. 

Here’s how to participate :
-Write a 100-word anecdote about your work with birds, bird encounters or about your love of birds.
-Let us know your name and send a self-portrait taken outdoors (300 dpi).
-List your five favorite birds. 
ec.oiseauxmigrateurs-migratorybirds.ec@canada.ca #BirdYear

The album will be a tribute to birds and all those who love them, volunteer bird observers, or those who have even devoted their career to bird conservation. The album will contain testimonials and photos of people. Here’s how to participate : -Write a -word anecdote about your work with birds, bird encounters or about your love of birds. -Let us know your name and send a self-portrait taken outdoors (300 dpi). -List your five favorite birds. ec.oiseauxmigrateurs-migratorybirds.ec.ca

Alberta’s East Buffalo Lake is a diverse landscape of wetlands, grasslands, and aspen forests. It hosts a multitude of breeding waterfowl and shorebirds, along with other wildlife.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada through the Natural Areas Conservation Program to protect this rich environment. http://ow.ly/raaW30f0Vfl

caption_original:
In 1966, NASA invited scientific groups from around the world to submit proposals to study lunar material from the Apollo 11 mission. The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) submitted several proposals, and all were accepted!

The GSC received the moon rocks and put them on display to the public. The collection included rock fragments, polished thin sections and soil. There was strong public interest, and long line-ups snaked their way into the GSC’s headquarters at 601 Booth Street!

If you live near Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, come visit Booth #9 at the Bio Expo 2017 this weekend and see how everyday electronics depend on earth’s rare metals.
http://ow.ly/vMFR30fiqJY
caption_cleaned: In , NASA invited scientific groups from around the world to submit proposals to study lunar material from the Apollo mission. The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) submitted several proposals, and all were accepted! The GSC received the moon rocks and put them on display to the public. The collection included rock fragments, polished thin sections and soil. There was strong public interest, and long line-ups snaked their way into the GSC’s headquarters at Booth Street! If you live near Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, come visit Booth at the Bio E this weekend and see how everyday electronics depend on earth’s rare metals.

nrcan.ifit-itif.rncan@canada.ca to register.
